author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Job creation schemes at risk from Brexit, business schools warn
text:
Job creation schemes at risk from Brexit, business schools warn 00:01, 9 Sep 2016 By Graeme Whitfield Many schemes where business schools work with local companies are EU-funded, an umbrella group is warning Shares Get business news by email Northumbria Uni Business School 
Business school projects that have created jobs and boosted companies in the North East are at risk following the vote for Britain to leave the EU, it has been warned. 
A report from the Chartered Association of Business Schools highlights the many projects funded by the EU - including a number of examples in the North East - that it says have made a significant impact on local business communities. 
Economic development programmes across the UK have led to increases in business income, profitability, productivity and created nearly 200,000 jobs since 2007, the Association says. 
But much of the funding for these schemes have come from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the European Social Fund (ESF), which will not be available to business schools once the Brexit process is complete. 
The Government has promised to protect funding for projects already underway, but there are no plans for how such projects will be funded after 2020. 
Professor Simon Collinson, chair of the Chartered Association of Business Schools - whose members include all five of the North East’s universities - said: “Whilst the Chancellor has given assurances for programmes that have already been given the green light, we need a commitment in the Government’s forthcoming Brexit strategy to fund economic development projects which support business growth, innovation and productivity through leadership programmes and R&D. 
“Without these projects and the interventions our world class business schools make with businesses in their areas, we risk a management skills deficit in the businesses and regions our economy needs to prosper after our exit from the EU.” 
Examples of job creation schemes in the North East which have been delivered through university business schools and funded by the EU include: A scheme to support the North East Automotive Alliance, helping companies benefit from the Nissan supply chain; A Northumbria University project that helped its graduates start their own businesses; Work at Sunderland University to improve the performance of small and medium-sized businesses by providing skilled graduates to do internships. Lucy Winskell OBE is pro vice-chancellor for business and engagement with Northumbria University 
Lucy Winskell, pro vice-chancellor for business and law at Northumbria University , said: “This report shows the far reaching contribution business schools like Newcastle Business School at Northumbria University make to the performance of small and medium firms, major multinationals and key parts of the public sector. 
“Northumbria University has a proven track record in working with commercial partners, where the university has added real value to these companies. Through excellent research, teaching and innovation we make a powerful contribution to economic development and regeneration, locally, nationally and globally. 
“Naturally we can prepare for if and when the availability of funding is less certain. But we will continue to increase the number of quality collaborations and build on existing partnerships such as those with Unilever, Nike, IBM, Nissan and Procter & Gamble from a real position of strength as the UK’s Business School of the Year.” 
The report calls on the Government to replace the European funds that will be lost to business schools after Brexit. 
It also highlights the value of collaboration between academics and businesses to improve the economy. More on the EU Referendum
